It told her not to be ashamed of the thundering inside her chest.

Everyone had names for it. Hunger. Desire. The press of it. It was all the same, something that moved through bones as tides do. They had other names too, but those she did not let touch her. Monster. Ogre. She knew what she was, and naming what she was seemed irreverent to the ogres of her childhood who had been spoken of in whispers, back when the hills were taller and radio stations stopped at midnight and you could hear the bats eating moths. She knew because when she was a girl, her aunt had looked at her hands and made the sign under the table. She knew because men’s eyes had slipped off her like rain down a rock face, and women had sometimes leaned into her shadow without knowing why.

Artists learned early where to look and where not to, which light loved them and which did not. Jolea was of the unlit spaces and of the kitchens where vinegar steam rose like a small amber fog, and of things put in jars because they were precious. She scraped the brush clean on a rag, pushing the paint solidly into its ruin. The woman in the dress almost smiled.

“You’re almost ready,” she said again, softer now. “We will see you soon, a little church of your own, a white light on you, people saying the right words. And then we’ll go.”

She had other work to do before morning. They always did.

On the other side of the last rain, the streets of San Juan were still roped with sun. The city had not slept; it never did, not really. The bougainvillea flamed from balconies, bikes leant against bakery windows, and tourists moved in little uncertain schools, mouths open like fish, laughing at their own jokes because it made the cobbles feel safer. Detective Chamberlain, hair in a knot that never seemed to lose a strand, slid sideways into the rear of a patrol car that smelled like coffee and jacaranda petals. The driver, a kid with a name that went with every generation of Puerto Rican baseball players—Omar, Bello, Junior—tipped his chin to her without stopping his stream of commentary about a reggaetón feud that had involved flamingos.

“Flamingos,” she repeated, “as in pink birds.”

He angled the rear-view mirror so that she could catch his white grin. “Plastic, Detective. Yard ornaments. Thousands of them, señora. It was a war of lawn.”

She didn’t smile, but privately she was laughing. It lived in her eyes, a little seam of light. She pulled a manila folder from her bag and wedged it against her thigh.

“They’re assigning you,” the kid said. “The boss said to swing past him first. Urgent. He did his urgent face.”

“Which one?”

“Thunder eyebrows. The little inhale before he speaks. Like he’s about to confess.”

“That one?” She let the smile show a little. “All right. And don’t ‘señora’ me.”

“I would never,” he said solemnly. “Señorita. Jefa.”

“Chamberlain is fine.”

People assumed the name meant she was not from here; then she said San Juan and they thought of someone else. The name came from her mother, who’d loved a singer and kept the name, even after the singer went. The rumor in the division called Chamberlain a stud. That word had glowered across kitchen tables when she was a teenager, back when she discovered that nothing felt better than stepping into a dance floor and owning it, hips serious, hands careless. She was soft-faced and hard-eyed, and no one who saw her walk in heels ever forgot it. She was a stud because she kept her heart in a pocket she never turned out. She was a stud because the old-timers respected her and the rookies wanted to live with the same kind of weather inside them: bright when needed, storm always at the edge. None of it mattered when the work presented itself and asked what it always did: Who are you, to look at this?

The work this time came with a smell.

“Art thing,” the Chief said, after the eyebrows and inhale. “Up on Calle de las Flores. Gallery. Owner says he found something he did not purchase inside his back room after last night’s private show. Something… attached. Literally attached, Marty. I’m saying that to be delicate.”

“You could save the delicate for the press.”

He sighed, sat back. Captain Izquierdo had the brow of a man who had spent his life thinking about night. He had given the stud nickname its first breath, delighted when it took on a life of its own. He wasn’t calling her that now, not in this office that smelled of citrus cleaner and xerox ink, but he was leaning across the desk in that way that said he wanted her to take the thing inside his head and carry it somewhere else. That the city was an animal and it came to her when it had a thorn stuck where its mouth could not reach.

“Some weeks ago,” he said, “we had three reports, scattered, of jars. The patrol found one on a bench, one at the pier, one left outside a hospital. No label. The contents were not… the usual. We did not connect them because we didn’t want to believe we should.”

Chamberlain let the folder lie unopened. Sometimes paper got in the way of the smell of something. Sometimes you had to wait to be told a story out loud so it could remember itself into the proper shape.

“I did not want this for you,” he said, softer now. “But I also know your body knows what to look for.”

She had not told him all the things her body knew. No one got the full ledger. But he was right: she recognized a certain flavor of shadow like a dog knows the smell of its pack.

“What is attached in the back room.”

“A little piece,” he said. “Taken from someone who is missing. A woman, if the knuckles tell us anything. Nothing else was in that room, except… a painting. The owner didn’t touch it. He swears he didn’t. Good for him.”

“Who else knows?”

“The neighbor. The bartender next door. The entire block will know in an hour. Can you go keep the block quiet.”

She stood and slipped the folder into her bag without opening it. She already had her pen between her fingers. “Yes.”

The gallery was a long, white tube with the acoustics of a chapel. Two paintings hung on the right wall: abstracts that looked like storms viewed through curtains of rain. On the left wall, a row of small frames held photographs of hands, not yet titled, each hand holding a mundane object with the gravity of a sacrament: a lighter, a spoon, a broken comb. The owner, a man whose linen shirt had lost a battle with the last hour’s sweat, waved his hands as if trying to direct a flock of birds. A woman from the bar next door leaned in the doorway, face sharp with curiosity.

“Officer,” the owner said, then corrected himself, “Detective. I didn’t touch it, I swear. The smell—my God—who would bring something like that in here?”

“You open the door in the morning and there it was?” Chamberlain asked, stepping inside, letting the gallery’s cool oil-and-white-wine scent fight with the sharpness crawling toward her down the hall.

“As soon as I turned the lights on,” he said. “Back room. Behind the curtain. I thought someone got drunk and left their things. Artists, you know, they leave their souls and their backpacks everywhere. But the smell…”

The word vinegar had not appeared yet, and Chamberlain did not want to give it any help. She motioned to the young officer posted by the curtain. He lifted the tape and she went under, ducking instinctively, as if the room were a low cave.

Inside, a painting stood propped on a crate. A woman kneeling in a dress the color of shellfish. The face unfinished. Hands lifted to her chest, palms turned heavenward. A jar beside the crate, lid off, vinegar seething the air with its clean, cruel promise. The thing inside the jar was pale, pruned by its bath, but whole. The room’s silence became a pressure against her lungs.

She covered the jar with its lid and closed it until the rubber seal sighed. It helped. The smell fell back a few paces, but it would never retreat all the way. Nothing that acid ever did. Chamberlain stood and looked at the painting for a long time. Above the kneeling figure, a smear of light suggested a window, and there, in the corner, so modest it was nearly a whisper of paint, a mark. Not a signature. Not a name. Something like a glyph. Notched, primitive. A “J” that refused to straighten all the way, as if bending beneath a burden.

She turned her head and heard the neighbor take a breath, heard her put a hand to her mouth. “Ay. Qué cosa. That’s, that’s from the other gallery. I saw a postcard with that woman in it. I swear.”

“The other gallery,” Chamberlain said calmly.

“Up on Calle de la Espera. The new one, with the stupid blue chairs. They sent invites around last week about a show, a woman who paints women. It was all very… you know, empowerment, glass of cava, power suits. My cousin went. She said it was a little too much.”

“What was her name? The painter.”

The neighbor tugged at the hem of her shirt as if it would jog her memory. “J something. Jole…” She closed her eyes, tried again. “Jolea? Jo-lee? That? Like the cola company. People were saying it weird on purpose. To feel special.”

Chamberlain pushed a thread of hair behind her ear and nodded to the officer. “Call it in. Quietly. Evidence team, discreetly as possible. Seal the front. For now, we say the air conditioning is broken, that’s all. You.” She pointed to the owner. “You do that voice you do when you tell people the artist is a genius. Use it to keep them at a distance. If anyone takes a photograph of anything in this room, I will personally teach them what their elbows are for.”

He nodded, gulped, performed the little bow that owners do when they are told to stand guard over something they do not understand but which is suddenly worth everything. Chamberlain walked out and into the sunlight, blinking hard.

The air outside was ripe with the woman who sold guava pastries at the corner and the bus exhaust and a whorl of perfume from the girl who brushed past at speed, eyes bright with the way running feels when you’re young and your body doesn’t yet argue. The city smelled like itself and a thousand strangers and like another thing, thin and lost, the vinegar ghost trying to catch up to her. She took her phone out and pressed speed-dial.

“You remembered?” Captain Izquierdo’s voice.

“Jolea,” she said. “An artist who paints women. The jar was a calling card.”

“You sound certain.”

“I’m certain,” she said, and realized when she said it that she was also angry. “And I’m tired of being certain with nothing to show for it but knots.”

“Are you good?” he asked. “Don’t get weird.”

“Me? Never.” She hung up and slid the phone into her pocket, as if burying it a second would let the heat move out of her palms and into the pavement.

She stayed on the sidewalk long enough to pretend she was observing the traffic pattern. People do not thank you for breaking bad news. They will say they want truth, but what they mean is that the truth must have good manners. She watched a man lift a baby into the air and kiss its foot. She watched a dog nose a grate and sneeze and do it again for pleasure. Her city held its own hand.

She didn’t notice him right away, the man who had stepped into the shade by the gallery door to see if she needed water. He held a plastic cup with condensation in his easy hand and the look of people who can make a crowded room feel uncomplicated: bartenders, nurses, good coaches. He was twenty-eight or thirty. He wore the shirt that said he spent his money on laundromats and sneakers, not on anything that would fail him when it rained. His name lived somewhere between his eyebrows and the corner of his mouth, waiting to be said.

“You’re the detective,” he said finally, offering the cup, unsure if proximity would offend. “I saw you at the book festival this spring. You asked the poet a question about windows.”

She took the water and held it against her temple. “Who are you.”

“Felipe,” he said. “I make coffee next door. I also sell the kind that pretends it will save your life.”

“Is that the kind with cinnamon and cayenne.”

“That is the one.”

“Good.” She sipped the water. “Felipe, do you know a painter named Jolea.”

He made the face of someone who recognizes the ring of a song but can’t sing the words back yet. “I know a woman who comes in with paint on her knuckles. They always wear long sleeves when it’s hot. That is when I worry. But she had big hands. Not like… I’m not trying to say masculine. Just capable. Like she could lift a truck. She smiled and you saw teeth, a lot of them. But also you felt like she was humoring the concept of smiling.”

“And she paid with cash.”

He laughed, surprised. “Yes.”

“I want you to tell my officer if she comes in here again. You do it like you’re telling him the weather. Quietly. Okay?”

He nodded, sobered, the inside of his eyes ticking through the possibilities. “I don’t like it,” he said. “I don’t like when something slides into the corner of a room like that and sits there and dares you to pretend it isn’t.”

“You and me both.”

He shifted. “Do you…” He seemed to be wrestling with the desire to ask her for something he would not name. A shield. A promise that stories ended with applause instead of with empty chairs.

“I can’t give you what you’re going to ask,” she said kindly. “But I can promise you I am good at swinging a thing when the thing needs to be swung.”

He allowed himself to look relieved, which wasn’t what she’d offered, but would do for now.

The evidence team arrived in a van that pretended not to be one. They moved like a string quartet: quiet and contained, letting each other breathe carefully. Chamberlain stood aside and watched them swallow the room. The owner wrung his hands and performed several versions of helplessness. The neighbor tried to film them through a gap in the curtain and stopped when Chamberlain’s head turned an inch in her direction. The young officer stood like a stake planted in a field.

It would have been different in any other city. Here, people knew to be theatrical about their grief and very practical about what must happen next. By nightfall, the jar would be on a table that had seen too many jars, and the lab’s old, mended fridge would hum dutifully in the corner. Tapes would run. Names would appear on lists. Somewhere, a mother would blink and know without wanting to how the feel of her own wrist was unique to anyone who had learned to wipe tears from a child’s face with the back of a hand, who had learned where the pulse lived. Somewhere, Jolea would be washing her brushes.

She was. Far from the white tube of the gallery, in her room that held its own weather, Jolea cleaned bristles with old-fashioned care, soap between thumb and forefinger, coaxing color to dissolve. She hummed under her breath, something her aunt had sung on long iron mornings when the house had had no money and no men and no patience for anyone’s tears. The words cracked like kindling in her mind, made from syllables that the radio rarely used anymore. She thought of the girl at the hardware store who had called her ma’am, but made ‘ma’am’ sound like a dare. The girl had a gap between her teeth and a laugh like a coin hitting a jar. She had wanted to paint the girl’s laugh, but one cannot paint sound. Not properly. Hands are easier. They carry the history of everything a life has touched.

She placed the brushes on a towel in order of size, a silly gentle rainbow. She put the lids back on three jars and wiped the condensation with a cloth so the skin beneath would not stick. She felt the familiar torque in her belly and did not apologize to anything for it. She had learned that sometimes the only prayer worth offering was the one you said to whatever piece of you refused to behave like furniture. Sit, you said. Stay. We will go together if you will pretend, for now, that we are one person. And it would, for a while.

When she slept, she dreamed of being very small and looking up the mountain and seeing the line of women bringing wash down to the river. She’d thought it was a parade. She’d thought the white flags meant celebration. The first time she lifted another woman’s hand, she’d thought of that line and how the laundry had waved to her and how the women had looked like they knew exactly what they were doing and exactly what would be taken from them for it. The hand she lifted had felt like a new tool, one she had owned all her life but not used properly.

Chamberlain sat at her desk with the city folded beneath her in maps and photos. The air conditioner had broken two days ago and the fan on her bookshelf wasn’t brave enough to move anything heavier than a paperclip, but she preferred the heat. It slowed other people down more than it did her. She liked to watch impatience melt off a suspect’s face. She liked to see a person choose to sit when a chair appeared out of nothing.

Her partner dropped into the chair across from her and swung his knee in a restless half-circle until she gave him a look. He put his hands on the desk, palms down, as if to prove that he could still. “We’ve got media. One of the bloggers already posted a picture of the painting from the other gallery’s invite. They did the thing, Marty. They put the images side by side.”

“I want their post taken down,” she said.

“They’re not going to.”

“Then I want the comments to look like a monastery. That, they will do.”

He leaned forward, curious. “Tell me how you turn a snake into a rosary.”

She told him the way she always did: call their sponsors. Make it about money, not decency. Threaten them with a thing that cost dollars instead of tears. He watched her shape the call, listened to the pleasantries, the gentle reminder of advertising budgets being a living thing that could move from one website to another, the suggestion that leaving the post up would make the brand seem like it liked to eat with dirty hands. She hung up and blinked, slow. He grinned.

“I will never understand why they call you a stud,” he said.

“Me neither,” she replied. “I do not wear leather.”

“You wear that face.”

“Which one.”

“The one that says, if you make me get up, you will regret making me get up.”

“You are projecting.”

He was not. She stood and rolled her shoulders back and picked up a little stack of photographs and held them so he would be forced to read detail instead of her posture. She treated detail like an old friend, the kind you could sit beside for hours without speaking and still feel you had told each other everything.

They went through the photographs: jars in odd places, placed like offerings on municipal altars. The bench, the pier, the hospital steps. No blood, no drama. The lids aligned carefully. The smell described with too many adjectives by the patrol officers because the mind, faced with certain things, tries to write them into metaphors so they don’t have to be named. The “J” mark in the corner of the postcard. The fact that the new gallery on Calle de la Espera was owned by a couple who had made a fortune selling energy drinks that tasted like panic and teenage sweat and now wanted redemption through culture.

Her partner, whose name was Reyes and whose mother had taught him to cook fish with three ingredients plus love, said, “And you think this woman is the one.”

“I do.”

“What’s your body say.”

“It says the smell isn’t an accident,” she said. “It says she discovered it and loved it and now it’s part of the ritual. Not in a religious sense. In a structural one. The way you salt water to taste. It says she may not even be hiding the jars because hiding would be insult to the thing she thinks she is doing.”

“Art.”

“Isn’t that what they always say,” she muttered, not bitter, just tired, and then smiled at a memory that had come to take a seat beside her. “My grandmother used to say that once you call something art, it moves out of the room and into another; it becomes someone else’s business.”

“She was wrong.”

“She was also right,” Chamberlain said. “That’s why I’m here.”

They ate papaya out of a plastic container while they reviewed witness statements. The fruit left a sweet smell that did not touch the vinegar. She thought of the poet who had spoken about windows and why we must open them even when we know what they let in, because without air we die, and laughed at the universe for being in such a humor. She thought of Felipe and how his face had gone from smooth to serious in a breath. She thought about hands and how they drown or save you depending on how you read them.

By dusk, the city glowed the way it sometimes did when everyone is sweating and nobody cares anymore. The sky went feral with pink. Musicians appeared on corners as if sprouted by humidity. She walked to the new gallery on Calle de la Espera, where the stupid blue chairs waited outside like patient birds. A woman in a pencil skirt and a shirt with a bow at the neck met her with a smile that had been tuned in rehearsal. Her partner went around back to check locks, to breathe behind the building and listen for lies from the dumpsters.

Inside, the walls wore women. The placards did the work that placards always do, telling you how to feel about the images before the images get a chance to do it themselves. “Radical Tenderness.” “Owning the Gaze.” “Hands Speak.” Chamberlain surprised herself by wanting to be venomous and then took the venom and put it in a jar on the shelf in her head because there would come a time when it would be useful.

A young person with hair like an exclamation mark pointed to a catalog and said the painter was new to them. Heard she was intense. Heard she didn’t like interviews. Heard she sold privately. Heard she never came to her own shows. Heard that she was tall, very tall, and built like a saint.

“Which saint,” Chamberlain asked dryly, but the kid didn’t catch it. He began to recite a list of saints as if that were a game people played. She walked away, and stood in front of a canvas where the woman’s hands were lifting something you could not see, something just outside the frame. The nails were painted a humble nude. The tendons ached with effort. There was that wash again, a varnish of something that made the air beside the painting taste like a penny. Her skin tightened. The “J” in the corner pretended to be a hair fallen from the painter’s head and trapped in the varnish. She tapped the placard with her pen.

“This one,” she said to the woman in the bow shirt. “When did you get it.”

“Three days ago,” Bow said. “It was delivered. We were told to hang it immediately. No name on the delivery. No return. Just the name on the invoice.”

“And the name.”

“J. O. L. E. A. That’s it.”

“And the hands with the spoon and the comb.”

“That was a collaboration with a photographer. They came together,” Bow said carefully. “They are… very popular.”

“Of course they are,” Chamberlain said.

She called the number on the invoice. It rang and rang and rang and a machine answered that didn’t have the decency to pretend to be a person. Her thumb hovered over the end call button and then she let it go to the last beep and left her voice there, a thread to follow later.

She would go home soon, to her apartment that she kept clean like a church you weren’t sure you believed in. She would drink water and stand in the dark by her window and look down at the street where a man sold mango slices in cups until midnight. She would look at her hands and think about how much of what people loved about her had to do with what she did with them in the space between a word and the next. She would think about calling someone and then she would put her phone down the way you put down a heavy book.

But not yet. She had one more thing to do. Outside, in the pink dark, she lifted her face to the last of the day and let the heat wrap her. Somebody was singing from a balcony. Somebody dropped a glass and laughed. She took out her pen and wrote the name on her palm as if writing it there would keep it from taking other shapes. Jolea.

Across the city, in the room with its weather, Jolea washed her hands in a bowl and watched the last light move through the water like a secret. She dried them with a towel that had belonged to someone who had taught her to do this with care. For a second, because she was human enough to be ridiculous, she imagined walking into a precinct and giving her name to a bored woman behind glass and being told to sit, someone will be with you, honey. It brushed her like a moth lands, light and uncommitted. She smiled, and the smile showed a lot of tooth, and she went to her easel and drew the first line of the next hand.

A storm stood on the horizon beyond the city, the kind that takes hours to make up its mind, that rehearses the sound of thunder until the trick is right. The gallery with the stupid blue chairs locked its glass doors and the couple who owned it retreated up the stairs to their apartment above, hand in hand. Felipe closed his café and pulled down the shutter and walked home along the route that made him feel safest. The neighbor from the other gallery made a video call to her cousin and they described the detective’s face to each other with the glee of people discussing a celebrity sighting. Captain Izquierdo sat on his sofa with his shoes off and watched a baseball game with the sound low, watching the pitcher’s hands more closely than he watched the ball.

Chamberlain, under her fan that didn’t do enough, didn’t sleep for a while. She read a page of a book and then the same page again because the words refused to sit still. Beneath the noise, beneath the city, a sound like liquid in a jar settled into the night’s nap. The air tasted faintly of something clean and cruel. It would take a lot for that taste to go away.

She dreamed of windows and the way they open when asked. She dreamed of a mountain road and a line of women bringing flapping sheets down to the river, white flags that were not surrender but announcement. A chorus. The tide in a person. She woke before dawn and neither she nor the city were ready to give up. The morning would read them like a palm, one line at a time.

Morning took the city in both hands and shook it awake, the light going gold in the puddles until they looked like melted coins, the rooster shouts braided into scooter engines and the first radios. Chamberlain ran the length of the promenade where the water pretended quietly that it did not have moods, her breath making a bright box around her when she exhaled. She did not run for virtue or vanity. She ran because it combed the snarls from her thoughts the way her grandmother had once combed her hair on a porch while telling her which windows in the neighborhood could be trusted. The vinegar ghost had stayed the night, a thread of it in the air the way a perfume clings to a scarf, and her body kept reading for it the way it read for tides, for the pulse in a stranger’s throat when the stranger thought they were being careful. The vendors were assembling their worlds. A man hawked mangos with a voice like a trumpet valve. A woman laid out seashell bracelets with practiced reverence. A child chased a paper bag that decided to fly. She finished her run, rolled her shoulders until the meat loosened over the bones, and set her face to the day like a worker ready for a stubborn gate.

At the lab, the fridge hummed a farmer’s hymn and the fluorescent lighting did what fluorescent lighting does to hope. Carla from evidence wore a scarf printed with chili peppers that did not belong in this room and therefore saved it a little. She slid a file and a plastic tray toward Chamberlain with the pride of a baker who knows her tart will make the room sit up and remember its manners. The jar had been cataloged like all the others, but someone had written a note on the corner of the form that said simply, again. It was the kind of note that belongs to a marriage in trouble and to a city learning where its edges are.

“We ran a quick panel,” Carla said, her voice pitched low, because even machines can be startled. “Acetic acid at five percent, like you’d expect from supermarket vinegar, but there’s also clove oil and black pepper and a whisper of bay. It’s not a marinade, it’s a memory. She wants it to smell the way kitchens sound when they’re making something that means all the women you knew were right.”

Chamberlain flipped a page. The gloss of the photographs always made her think of maps in a geography textbook. “And the hand.”

“The skin took the bath without rage. No immediate postmortem hemorrhage in the surrounding tissue, so she took it after death, or she got lucky with a vein. Manicure was cheap and cheerful, drugstore brand, nude with a blush. There are micro-abrasions on the ring finger that say a ring was removed quickly and recently, and there’s a faint trace of a citrus cleanser on the knuckles. People who clean counters for a living, or people who love their kitchen too much. There’s a fragment of cotton thread snagged under the nail, off-white, cheap twine. The lid shows prints, partials, none clean, and a thumbline that says the person who closed it had a broad pad and a scar you can just taste in the whorl.”

“We can love for fingerprints,” Chamberlain said, not unkind, “but let’s not fall in love. The brand of jar?”

“Imported. The kind they sell by the case to home picklers and DIY witches. We pinged a few suppliers,” Carla said, and smiled at the expression this provoked, a smile that said yes, I have already done the thing you were about to ask for. “Hardware stores mostly. The one on Calle del Sol made a bulk order three weeks ago to someone named Luna. Cash. The receipt is a photocopy of a photocopy, but the girl at the register told our guy that the customer had hands like shovels and eyes that didn’t stick to anything for long.”

Chamberlain let the smile loosen her mouth. She tucked the lid back on the jar for the second time in as many days and set the anger she respected more than she liked on the chair beside her. “Luna,” she said. “Of course.”

“Of course,” Carla echoed. “She also bought twine, a gallon of cleaning vinegar, and three painter’s drop cloths. No brushes. No canvases. As if those belong to a different wallet.”

Reyes met her in the hallway with an apple the size of a fist and a list that felt like a prayer with a hole in it. Missing women from the last six months, ages inconsistent, neighborhoods ranging, but their work histories chimed like spoons on a glass. A piano teacher who gave lessons on weekends out of a living room that smelled like basil and powder. A masseuse who’d started in hotels and moved to a storefront because she preferred hearing her own music. A pastry chef with a scar on the thumb you get from careless caramel. A hairbraider who sat on a plastic chair in a doorway and made strangers into family in the time it takes to tell a story. A hospital aide with forearms like rope who loved the newborn unit and sang to the ones that cried at night.

“Hands,” he said, and his voice didn’t hide its ache at the neatness of the pattern. “You asked me to look sideways and there it is. She’s shopping where hands do the talking.”

“Where hands know their names,” Chamberlain said. “She doesn’t want a mystery. She wants a calling. She’s self-mythologizing with vinegar.” She studied the photos, the way the wrists connected the story to the body, the way even the blur of surveillance could not make a person anonymous if you watched with love. “We’ll go to the hardware store. We’ll bring flowers.”

“Flowers?”

“For the girl at the register,” she said. “I’d like her to tell me everything without having to convince herself she owes me nothing.”

The hardware store kept its own weather, a dry, metallic smell of tin and competence, the aisles as straight as a soldier’s back. The ceiling fans worked as if they had made a pact with the heat to keep everything civil. The girl with the gap in her teeth was on a step stool arranging a pyramid of paint cans that would topple if anyone breathed the wrong way. She hopped down when she saw the badges, her face doing that thing faces do when they have a story and have been waiting for someone to come and ask for it by name. Chamberlain watched her put her spine straight and her chin at a cooperative angle, which told her the girl had decided what kind of adult she wanted to be and was practicing.

“I sold her the jars,” the girl said, after the first exchange of pleasantries and the placing of a paper bouquet of marigolds wrapped in brown craft paper on the counter. “I thought she was going to pickle green mango, that’s what my aunt does in summer. She had cash, big bills, and she counted them the way my abuelo used to count his dominoes, with his thumb and forefinger rubbing the corner of each and making a little click. She smelled like… not perfume, not soap, but like the way your kitchen smells after you clean up from a party. She had paint on the side of her hand, right here, and she wore a long-sleeve shirt and her wrists were like rope, and I thought, if she asked me to help her carry something, I would say yes without knowing why. I didn’t like that I thought that. I didn’t like that I said yes in my head.”

Chamberlain felt the little lift the girl’s voice gave to yes when she remembered it, and she didn’t miss that the girl had already written herself a cautionary tale and pinned it up where she could see it. “She gave a name,” Chamberlain said. “Or was given one by your system.”

“Luna,” the girl said, and closed her eyes as if to see the moment again in better light. “But the way she said it, it sounded like a joke she made with herself. She looked at me as if to ask if I could see the punchline.”

“What did she look at when she smiled,” Chamberlain asked, and the question slowed the room. The girl thought, thrilled by the quality of attention she had been offered, the way the detective had adjusted the instrument and waited for the pitch.

“The shelves,” she said finally, surprised. “Not me. Like she was smiling at the idea of shelves. Like everything that holds things deserves a medal.”

Reyes bought a box of nails he didn’t need so that money changed hands and gratitude might have a reason to sit and stay. They left with the printout of the receipt, the girl’s number in case she remembered something in the shower, and a small paper bag that contained a washer because she’d insisted on giving the detective something light to put in her pocket for luck. In the street, a man went by on a bicycle carrying a ladder, and people parted around him like water parts for a fish that knows where it is going. The sun pinned everyone to their shadows, and the city smelled like metal and sugar and the start of rain weeks away.

Jolea moved through a market not far away with the grace that comes from spending a life learning what to do with the space around you. She liked markets in the morning because they were still half asleep and because the people there were working, which meant they were not performing work for photographs. The fishmonger had three gallons of clear white vinegar in his stall, tucked behind the bucket where he kept the lemon halves. He called her heart, everyone was heart to him, and she bought one gallon and a handful of limes she didn’t need. She touched an octopus the way you touch a cat you don’t want to wake and felt the dream still in it, the slack holy weight of a thing that had once thought itself invincible. The radio in the plantain stand reported on traffic with the solemnity of a funeral and on art with the glee of a child faced with cake; the anchors said a name and said it wrong and said it again and wrong again because keeping it wrong made it feel special. She listened and thought, all names are wrong until they are whispered inside the right mouth, and at the same time an old fear put its hand on her neck and squeezed gently in reminder.

She noticed a woman kneeling on a plastic mat at the edge of the plaza, chalking a bird on the pitted concrete for no one and everyone. The chalk was cheap, it left dust on the woman’s fingers that matched her shirt and did not care. People stepped wide around her without meaning to, as if she were a wet spot. The woman used the side of her hand to smudge the wing into a suggestion of motion and in that simple thickening of shadow she had made the bird sing. Jolea had a rule about joy. She did not bite into it. She did not put her hands on it. She carried it until it went cool and then she put it down gently, the way you return a book to the library the day it is due because you know exactly what it cost to write.

Felipe’s café was open by then, the metal shutter lifted, the smell of cinnamon floating out first like an ambassador arguing for a soft treaty. He was counting the till and humming an old coro that had no right to still be in the air, and he looked up when the bell rang because, despite everything, we always look up. She was taller than he had made her in his mind, and it annoyed him that he had done that thing, made her smaller so the world would fit better. Her sleeves were rolled, and there were pale lines on her forearms that weren’t scars so much as they were instructions. “Coffee,” she said, and the way she said it did not ask for options. He made what he always made when he didn’t want to give a person a weapon, milk and sugar in proportions that soothed, a cinnamon line across the top the way you mark a road for people who forget themselves. She drank, and some of the steel in her mouth went to sleep.

He wanted to be a good citizen. He wanted also to live a long time and not be remembered for being a good citizen because that sometimes disinvites you from old age. His hand went under the counter to the button that called the officer posted two doors down, and he pressed it with the tenderness he uses for pastry with soft middles. He kept talking like talking was music. “You paint,” he said, and the question wasn’t a question. “I can tell because people who sand furniture also come in here, and they don’t look like you. You look like you argue with light and win.”

“Sometimes,” she said, and the smile she allowed him bent only at the very edges, a courtesy bow, not a surrender. “Sometimes I lose and I call it learning.”

“The show up the street,” he said, which was also not a question because he had never yet seen anyone who fit into their own rumor with such ease. “They say you don’t come to your own openings.”

“I don’t,” she said, and placed her cup on the counter with a click that his body felt in places he did not name. “Too much weather.”

The officer who lived two doors down wandered in the way a cat wanders into a kitchen as if kitchens were nature. He asked for something cold and let his eyes adjust to the temperature of the room, which is what good officers do when they don’t want anyone to notice them measuring. Felipe loosed a sentence into the air with the casual intimacy people use with weather. “Hey, this new cinnamon supplier is a saint, right? And it’s going to rain later, I can feel it in my shoulder.” The officer said he could feel it in his knee, which was not true, he was twenty-four and nothing in his body had ever complained. He looked at the woman only once and let the glance slide off with respect, which is to say he did not let his eyes investigate her hands like a thief reading the locks of a door.

Jolea had never in her life undercounted a room. The press of eyes is the first weather you learn to name. She knew what Felipe had done and she did not resent him for it. This city dressed its people in caution born of a long marriage to water and heat and colonizers and tourists. She took another sip. She looked at a poster on the wall not even long enough to read it, the way people look away from a mirror when they are not ready to meet themselves. She put a five-dollar bill on the counter and a coin and a small thread of paint from her sleeve, which stuck to the sugar, and then she left with the smallest backward tilt of her head that might have been a thank you or might have been her measuring the size of the door. The officer waited two breaths and then went outside after her in the manner of dogs who do not bark. Felipe picked up the cup and washed it as if washing could make the future less certain.

Reyes was already on the block when Chamberlain arrived, the sort of timing that makes partners feel like twin engines of the same plane. He took one look at the angle of her mouth and said, “We missed her by less than this,” and held thumb and forefinger a whisper apart. The officer described her without touching the words that would have made her monstrous and focused instead on the cadence of her step, the way shoes meet ground when a person has learned to be sweet to their knees. Chamberlain stood in the doorway of the café and let the cinnamon draw a net across her breathing. She could feel the wake in the air, the small charge rooms keep after a storm passes across them and decides to leave other houses alone.

“She turned on Callejón de los Lobos,” the officer said. “Then nothing. The alley spits you out onto the whole world.”

Chamberlain walked the alley anyway. It smelled like onions and the bad perfume of angel trumpets after rain, and it held the kind of shade that has seen violence and games of jacks with equal frequency and learned to treat both like weather. The walls had posters that described politicians with the language of lovers and bands with the language of revolutions. A chalk bird smudged by a shoe watched her from the ground with one eye. She ran a finger over the line of its wing and clean white came away on her skin, the city making a mark and a detective carrying it whether she wanted to or not. She touched her tongue to it like a child to a battery and felt, absurdly, the faint tang of lime.

They did the prudent things that look like nothing and are everything. They spoke to the woman who sold limes and to the old man who pretended to read a newspaper that had been yesterday’s for three days. They stood with the shade of a flamboyán tree and let ten people tell them the same story because there is something holy in seeing the edges shift depending on the mouth that holds them. By noon it was too hot to be interesting, which is the hour the island keeps for the people who know how to rest. Chamberlain used it to go sit where the jar had sat on the gallery’s crate and asked the room which prone objects tell the truth and which lie. The tape crossed the door like a melody you hum without wanting to. In the corner, the “J” had dried the way oil dries, slow and sure, and just under the paint, beneath the varnish, beneath the white like a thin breath, there was a hair. Not fallen merely. Intentionally embedded. Red-brown, coarse, stubborn as wire.

She called Carla back into the cool of her kingdom and the lab tech plucked the hair with chopsticks as if it were a piece of grilled squid and laughed once at herself for thinking of food now. “If she gave us her own,” Carla said, “it’s because she thinks that when you touch it, you will hear her voice and know you have been chosen for a story.” Chamberlain didn’t say out loud that some people get the villain’s letter and keep it in a shoebox for years and touch it when they want to feel like the main character. She watched the hair go into its tiny bed under glass. She imagined the machine that would whisper to it until it told them more secrets than anything is comfortable telling to a stranger.

When the sun rolled a little and people began to pretend the afternoon breeze was doing a job it did not do, a call came from a church that had decided to be relevant in the way old churches do, with a soup kitchen and a literacy night and a sheltered portico where people lay a while when the city’s lap feels hard. A jar was on the first step, no note. The lid was screwed down so that a person’s wrist would have to believe in itself to open it. A volunteer with a habit of courage had put her palm to it and then thought better. She had called. Chamberlain sat on the step and asked Reyes to sit on the one below her because sometimes solving a problem is a matter of where you put your body. The priest, a man with a mustache that wrote its own biography, hovered and talked about mercy and about thieves who took candles and about the glory of women’s hands when they lifted pots that weren’t light.

“Mercy is complicated,” Chamberlain said, not for him, but because she knew her partner would let the sentence sit inside him and not shake it until it meant something else. The jar had something curled inside that was not flesh. A glove. A hand-shaped glove, bleached and soft and floating like a jellyfish. The vinegar sang anyway. There were petals in it, white and thin as fingernails. Gardenias. She unscrewed the lid because sometimes you have to let a smell out so something else can breathe. It hit her soft and mean at once, the way love does when it has done its inventory and found you insufficient. Reyes made a noise that could have been a laugh if laughter wore boots. “She’s practicing her calling cards,” he said, and lowered his eyes, either out of respect or because he didn’t want them to betray the place where worry keeps its honey.

There are days when the city gives you nothing and days when it gives you three things you did not ask for, all green and stubborn as papayas left on the counter too long. At the new gallery with the blue chairs, an envelope had arrived addressed in a hand that wanted to be seen. Inside, a postcard printed on thick paper that smelled a little like almonds informed the owners that another painting was on its way with instructions for lighting, the way some people tell you how to cook the pasta they bring to a potluck. The note was signed with the bent “J” and a line that was almost a heart except that it wasn’t, not at all, not the shape or the impulse. The owners, who had decided that their money would sound better if it were filtered through culture, looked at each other and then at Chamberlain and told the truth by accident. “We cannot send it back,” they said, “we’ve already sold the story to ourselves.” She told them that if a truck arrived with a box, they were to keep it closed and call her, and if any person tried to cut a string they were to imagine the string was a vein and act accordingly.

In the room that had learned her mouth, Jolea painted the corner of a window so that light could sit in it and get its breath back. She had washed her hands until they were pink and then she had pressed them to the wall and left the prints there like animals do, the print too faint for a falsifiable narrative and strong enough to make her feel like she could find home again if the power went. She thought of the church steps and of the old woman who would pass her fingers over the jar the way you pass your fingers over a child’s hair when it’s been cut too short. She thought of the chalk bird and its wing smudge, delighted that the city had answered her back without understanding she’d asked a question. The vinegar sang and she sang under it, lower, the harmony that makes it feel like a kitchen when the rain is behaving and the child is napping and your neighbor is asleep with the radio on. She pulled a strand of her own hair loose and placed it on the canvas and brushed varnish over it, and the varnish did what varnish does to acts of faith and foolishness, preserved them without promise of judgment.

At home that night, Chamberlain stood by her window with the glass open because pretending the air outside is different from the air inside can give you enough hope to sleep. Across the street, a couple argued about peanut butter with the urgency of people who know that the peanut butter is not what they mean. A boy practiced a trumpet in polite bursts and the notes fell like rubber balls and then bounced higher when his teacher’s voice came through the phone and told him to use his belly. She drank water and felt it go to the places inside that always surprise her by being new every time she notices them. She thought of the missing women’s hands as citizens, with opinions and passports and the weary patience of the competent. She lay down and made a list in her head of the things she would not do tomorrow if she could help it, chief among them, let her anger decide which way her feet went.

She dreamed of the old stories that lived under the bed when she was a girl and how her aunt had not dismissed them out of hand, had not told her that the things with teeth lived only on television. The aunt had taught her to say goodnight to the dark as if it were a person who could be hurt by neglect. In the dream, ogres sat at a table shelling beans, the slow domesticity of a universe in which names and mouths and hunger sit down together and negotiate. One looked up with a face that was many faces and said, in a voice like a wet gust, we were here before you learned to hide the knives. We were here when you were a river. We will be here when you call us something kinder because you need to sleep. She woke with her hand under her cheek and the crease of her palm pressed to her mouth like a stamp you pay too much for but keep anyway because it is beautiful.

In the morning, before even the coquí confessed that they were done with night, a truck nosed into the alley behind the stupid blue chairs and a man with a clipboard looked at the address as if the numbers in this city were strangers who spoke to him only when they felt like it. Reyes had fallen in love with the universe enough to be early. He leaned on the doorjamb and let the delivery man carry the story to him in his own words, words about not knowing art and not wanting trouble and about how a person’s back is a finite resource. Chamberlain arrived on foot, coffee in one hand and the small washer in her pocket blessing or doing nothing. She watched the box come off the truck with the care people reserve for objects they fear will either explode or break into a mundane mess that will need sweeping. The owners hovered again. Bow was there with her practiced smile and her need to narrate, and even she went hush when the crate sat on the floor like a sleeping dog.

They did not open it. They walked around it as if it were the center of a neighborhood. Chavez from evidence put a gloved hand on the wood and closed his eyes as if wood can tell you the last hand to touch it, and in this city sometimes it can. The label said only FRAGILE and a telephone number that went to a recorded voice that said the inbox was full. Chamberlain crouched, because you always crouch when you want something to confess. On the underside of the crate, in chalk, a glyph. Not quite a J this time. Bent deeper, as if the weight had increased or the burden had been indulged. She blew on it as if it were cake. The chalk did not move. Sometimes you want things to be dramatic so you know where to put your hands.

By noon she had twenty messages from people with opinions about the word ogre and six from reporters who were falling in love with the story the way a freshman falls in love with a professor. She called none of them back because the press was hungry for different meat than this and because she wanted time with the crate the way you want time with the body of a friend at a wake, not because you think you can change anything, but because touch is a letter you can send that still gets delivered. She thought of Felipe and of the way he had smoothed the surface of his fear with a line of cinnamon. She thought that she would go have the coffee that lies about saving you. She thought: do not let the person you’re hunting learn you’re religious about anything you aren’t willing to give up.

When she reached the café, his face did the thing people’s faces do when they are relieved and sad at the same time, delight a step behind worry. He told her he had seen the woman who smelled like a party had already happened, and he told her that he did not want his name to be in papers because there are names that become stories and names that become cautionary tales, and he did not want his mother to get phone calls that required her to stand at the sink and look out the window while she steadied her voice. Chamberlain told him she would do what she could. She did not promise. They stood with their cups sweating in their hands like people who had just danced without meaning to and were pretending their breath came easy. Outside, a child ran past them with a bucket on his head, laughing at the new weather he had made for his face.

Across the city, in a room that obeyed and defied humidity by turns, Jolea leaned toward her easel and practiced a small mercy. She mixed a color that was not flesh and not sky and not stone but the idea of a thing seen through water, and she laid it along the throat of the kneeling woman in the dress the color of shellfish until the breath there looked like it belonged to someone. She did not finish the face. She would not do that until the last minute. Faces tell the truth without consent, and she liked to let lies think they were working a little longer than they deserved. On the floor beneath the window, under a scrim of sunlight she made with a hand, a line of jars waited without impatience because glass does not have that habit. She could feel the storm that had been practicing all week flexing itself in the distance like a man who touches his bicep when no one is looking, and she hummed around the vinegar’s thin song, a counterpoint that would make the thunder feel obligated to show up decent.

By evening, the crate had acquired spectators, because anything becomes a plaza if you let eyes accumulate. Chamberlain had a velvet rope put around an object she had never thought she would rope, and she let Bow give a speech to no one about delays and authenticity and process while she watched the hallway and the door and the window that had been painted shut at some point in the gallery’s history out of laziness or fear. The city was in a mood to sweat and forgive. The bloggers had prepared their headlines. The Captain had prepared his eyebrows. Reyes had prepared three jokes he would not get to tell. Someone somewhere lifted a lid and the clean, cruel smell walked out into the night like it owned it, which, for the hour it took to cross from one end of the barrio to the other, it did.

When they opened the crate at last, with the boring tools that mend as well as they break, when they eased the nails out like a splinter you get at the beach and don’t want the child to cry about, when the lid came free and the canvas inside breathed its first breath in this room, there was the woman again, kneeling, dress like shellfish, hands lifted in the position that says either take this from me or give me more, I cannot tell. The face had come along enough to have a mouth, and the mouth was not smiling, not almost smiling, not pretending anything at all. Behind her, a window had been painted so that it shone like a thing lit from within. In the corner, small and private and arrogant, the “J” bent deeper and deeper until it was nearly a hook. And on the crate’s bottom, placed with the tenderness of warfare or love, a jar. The lid was tight. The vinegar sang. Inside, floating like an answer to a question no one had admitted asking, was a single pearl, real or false it did not matter, orbited by a lock of hair the color of a late afternoon alley. The hair drifted toward the pearl and drifted away again in slow complaint.

Reyes swore under his breath in the language he used for prayer and for frying food. Bow made a small noise and put her hand to her bow, as if remembering it could be undone. Chamberlain lifted the jar and felt its weight and did not apologize to the impulse in her body that wanted to smash it on the floor and watch the contents scatter because sometimes destruction is a way of finding out what the world is made of. She set it down instead. She said nothing. The city listened, because a silence like that is news.

The pearl looked foolish in the vinegar, as if it had wandered into the wrong story and was too proud to excuse itself. Chamberlain watched it orbit the lock of hair and think better of pressing closer, the way people in elevator cars recalculate their choices without moving their feet. They logged the crate, they logged the canvas, they logged the jar and the chalk and the screws saved in a cup because someone remembered the way cases go sideways when a detail is discarded for being boring. Bow insisted on a photograph of the scene for insurance, and Chamberlain allowed it with the kind of patience that grows in swamps. She asked for the invoice number to be blessed into her hands and Bow made copies with theatrical reluctance as if paper could bruise. Reyes ran the number through a catalog of ghosts and came up with a shipping office that did not have a counter, only a lockbox and the promise that a person would come if you called twice and said please with the correct rhythm. They stood in the street with the sun picking out unkind truths and felt the case lengthen by one more room they would have to walk through.

The shipping man came sweating and apologetic in a shirt that had given up and said the name on the paperwork had been a corporation registered in Delaware that had been invented two weeks before it was needed. He did not say shell company because he was a man who thought metaphors made him unprofessional, but the shells gathered in the air anyway. The crate had been dropped at a different address first, a warehouse on the edge of the piers that rented its air by the hour, a place the city used for parties it did not want to admit to. The driver who signed out the job was a freelance and his phone number had already folded itself neatly into the pocket of the past, out of service, unavailable, a polite phrase for gone. Chamberlain thanked the shipping man with a face that excused him from guilt and asked him to call her if he remembered which music played on the radio when the crate was loaded because sometimes that kind of memory turns the key in a story’s side door. He seemed flattered and promised, and she didn’t roll her eyes because she didn’t have a use for contempt that day.

At the lab, Carla Varela leaned over the pearl as if it might confess to being calcium carbonate and childhood both. She said it was a pearl without sentence, likely real, slightly scarred where it had rubbed against something not kind, perhaps deliberately. The hair agreed with the hair from beneath the varnish in its appetite for being stubborn, and when asked what else it wanted to tell, it opened its mouth as far as a hair can and said, in the language of isotope and contamination, that it had never lived near bleach and that its owner preferred soaps that smelled like plants instead of pianos. The vinegar’s chorus came back the same, diction clear, notes of clove and bay again, but there was something new, a flirt of allspice, a darker, rounder thing that made Carla’s eyes do a little pleased dance. She looked at Chamberlain over the glass and said, this person is cooking a memory and adjusting seasonings as she eats. Chamberlain nodded as if someone had reminded her to salt her own water, to taste and not just feed.

They decided to go stand at the warehouse and make it behave like a place where conversations happen. Reyes called in a favor to a woman who worked nights and knew where all the cameras in the city were pointing and why, and she gave them a view of the alley where the crate had spent an hour sweating in its wood. The footage was the color of weathered coins. A truck nosed in, a man stepped down, he had the posture of an old athlete, he did not look around as much as he should have. Another person walked past and did not look at the camera at all, which is how you see someone who understands the economy of attention. This person wore a long-sleeved shirt in heat that made the lines in the air wiggle, and the hands were visible only when they lifted to touch the crate, open-palmed, a sweet greeting offered to a beast. It could have been anyone. Except it wasn’t, because the camera caught the shape of a watch strap that had known real years and not just fashion, and caught the sense of gait you cannot teach to anyone who hasn’t lived with hunger and made it a companion instead of a leash.

Jolea didn’t enjoy the warehouse or the block-long rooms that smelled like old wine and damp pallets. She hated the fluorescent insistence. She hated the way sound behaved like a mosquito in rooms like that. But it had been necessary because the new gallery with its blue chairs had a concierge, and she had chosen not to practice talking to concierges this summer. She had been careful. She had chosen a shirt the color of water pretending to be deeper than it was and a hat that made her forehead less honest. She had spoken to the driver the way you speak to an uncle you might need one day, no pleading, no charm, just the facts of an exchange. She had slipped him cash with the softness of greasy paper and the driver had not counted it in front of her because he respected certain rituals. She had watched him lift the crate and thought of the old men who played dominos under the tarp behind the market, how the sound of tile on tile could hypnotize you into telling the truth to the wrong person. She had left with the taste of fluorescence on her teeth and had gone home to rinse with vinegar because you fight one weather with another.

The woman with the chalk did not appear the next day in the plaza, and Jolea told herself not to look for her because looking makes the universe sly. Plenty of chalk women would appear in time. Plenty of hands called to her with their callouses and their rings and their absence of both. Meanwhile, she needed tarps. The drop cloths from the hardware store had shown her their cheap seams and frayed themselves into stupidity. Her aunt used to say that craft takes money the way plants take water, without apology, and the only question is whether you pour into the right pot. She went to a supplier at the edge of Santurce who sold the kind of canvas you could pitch a life under. The man there tried to flirt with her and then tried to flirt with the idea of being afraid of her when he realized flirting annoyed her, and she gave him half a smile that made him decide his day had gone well anyway. She took extra canvas she had told herself she did not need and straps for carrying what you cannot explain to a taxi driver. On her way back, she paused in front of a barbershop where a woman braided hair so fast that you wanted to applaud. The braider’s hands were kingdom and blade both. Jolea stood there until the child in the chair noticed her and made a face at her through the glass, and Jolea made a face back, terrible and gentle, and the child put a hand to her stomach in the universal gesture for I laughed too hard.

Felipe told himself not to stare when the detective came in and sat like a person who trusted the chair because she had made friends with the idea that wooden things hold you up. She asked for the thing with cayenne and cinnamon and he made it indulgent because there are days you feed the body sugar because the mind has been fed vinegar. He bent low and spoke the way a person does when the room begins to grow permission. He asked if anyone had been hurt because of the thing he had done, and she told him no in a voice without fat. He asked if he had been useful and she said yes. He asked if she would like a slice of banana bread that did not change the world and she said yes again because she wanted to teach his hope that yes existed outside of emergency. He told her that when the woman was in his shop, she spoke about weather like it was a pet she was training, and that she had looked briefly at the corner where a jar of sugar sits because his grandmother liked to keep pretty things near the work. Chamberlain closed her eyes and held the cup to her nose and let the cinnamon insist, and then she opened them and told him that there would be a car on his corner for a while, that he might see it and then not see it and that this would not mean it wasn’t there. He nodded, and when she left, he told the sugar jar out loud that it was not to flirt with visiting customers anymore.

Captain Izquierdo had been a young patrolman when he learned that the only time he needed to talk loudly in the bullpen was when he wanted cops to be quiet. He did the eyebrows, he did the inhale, and he told the room to sit because he had to say a thing that made everybody itch. He told them to stop saying the words they had been saying to each other in the hallway about monsters and lunatics because he wanted the case to belong to hands instead of to myths. He reminded them that the island owed too many graves to people who had thought that naming something evil excused them from the work of the day. He put a photograph of a hand on the whiteboard, not the hand from the jar because he had taste, but a photograph from the other exhibit, the one with the spoon. He said this is what we look at, this is all we look at, because hands hold more truth than faces, faces rehearse, hands get caught. When somebody muttered about witches, he said there were women in his family who boiled cinnamon sticks and orange peel every Sunday morning because they liked the way it made the house behave and maybe that was witchcraft and if so, he preferred to have brunch with witches.

Chamberlain let him be the toastmaster and used the time to sit on the floor with Reyes and the folder of missing persons and not be careful about her knees. Reyes had circled the hospital aide’s file twice, not because he liked the neatness of its dates but because buried in an interview transcript was a sentence about how she bought jars from a particular discount store because she liked the sound the lids made when you closed them properly. He had drawn a star beside it in red pen, not because he thought it proved anything but because it had made his breath misbehave. The aide’s sister had been the one to report her missing, and she had left a voicemail that had stayed in the system because the IT guy happened to have a crush on the sound of voices. They listened. The sister said, she was tired, you could hear it, but she liked to say that tired is different when it comes from loving the thing that makes you tired. She talked about how her sister rubbed lotion into her own hands at night like they were babies, and how she wore a cheap ring because it let her pretend she’d already been chosen. The micro-abrasions on the ring finger in the lab report came and sat beside that sentence and did not act like strangers.

They went to the hospital with coffee the way soldiers bring flags, solemn and insufficient. The nurse manager who met them had the eyes of someone who has slept and eaten in fits all her life and made peace with the schedule. She said the aide had been sweet on the babies and gruff with the men and had arms she used like shields when the world tried to forget what she’d given it. She said nobody suspicious had hung around except for the world at large. She said there had been a woman in a long-sleeved shirt who came asking about volunteer opportunities in the maternity ward and how the front desk had told her there was a long list and how the woman had smiled like the list was a dare. The camera over the front doors had a view of the back of the woman’s head in a hat, and the view of her shoulder when she turned to leave no more reliable than the moon through bougainvillea. Chamberlain stood for a long time in the hallway outside newborn, watching the tiny engines breathe, and she felt inside her chest the precise weight of her heart and how it had learned to be heavy and light on command.

Late afternoon in the barrio is a place where choices get made in kitchens. Jolea washed the mouth of a jar and thought of a classroom where someone had told her that the thing that separates human beings from other animals is not the use of tools but the use of storage, the way we save the world for later and imagine we’re being prudent. She had been about to laugh and had stopped because the teacher meant it. She thought now about storage and about vows and about the way putting anything in a jar made it holy for a second regardless of what the thing was. She pulled a strand of hair from her head, not in the deliberate, pained way she had done for the varnish, but with impatience because the hair had fallen into her eye and the day had begun to ask impolite questions. She wound the hair around her finger and watched it hold the shape for a brief second and then try to go back to itself. She dropped it in the sink and it clung to porcelain like any animal. She shook her hands and thought, I am a storage animal, a room with jars for ribs, and I am tired of thinking about whether it is sin to eat when food is placed in front of you.

She went out into the evening with a bag over her shoulder that did not look heavy and a line of vinegar singing her nerves into something like patience. The chalk woman was back at the plaza. She was drawing the outline of a hand, not her own, larger than life and not heroic so much as honest, the fingers blunt and the knuckles complicated. A child handed her a plastic cup of water as if he were knighting her, and she sipped and took a breath and went back to the place where the thumb meets the palm as if that were a seam she could mend. Jolea thought of her aunt and the sign under the table and how it had meant, we see you and we will pretend we don’t so that you can grow up in privacy. She thought about kneeling on concrete and how your knees find a way to forgive you, and she went to buy the woman a sandwich because she has learned to use food to tell the world she can be gentle. The woman thanked her without suspicion and tore the sandwich into two and handed half back without the ugliness of ceremony. They ate like animals do, neat but aware that there is always a hawk somewhere, and did not say anything that could be used as evidence of intention.

Chamberlain had the sense, honed over years of being paid to let the world talk to her, that she was late for a conversation the city was having without her. It made her impatient in the way heat makes people impatient, a removal of polite skin. She drove the long slow way past walls she liked and corners she trusted to hold her if she needed to press her shoulder into brick and think. She ended up at her grandmother’s building without meaning to, because the body knows the route to the mouth that taught it to speak. The woman was gone, had been for years, the building now held a yoga studio and a shop that sold dresses the color of fruit you eat guiltily. But the stairwell still smelled like cabbage and detergent, which is to say like survival, and she let the smell fill her with a memory of being told the difference between an open door and a door that looks open. She sat on the step until someone passed and gave her a nod that said, we all came here to be alone together for a minute, and then she got up and went back into the heat to find the thing that had come to sit at her table and ask for water.

The blog that would not take down its post had moved from appetite to appetite, and now people were posting photographs of their own hands in support of or in outrage against the idea that anyone could possess anyone’s hand, even for a second. The photographs filled the internet for an afternoon the way swallows fill dusk, and some of them were beautiful and some of them made Chamberlain want to sleep for a week because virtue and theater use the same tools. Reyes read the comments he shouldn’t have and took his phone and put it in the freezer for ten minutes because his grandmother had taught him that heat can be frightened away by colder heat. When he took it out, the little fog in the camera lens made the world look like it had been polite enough to cry in private. He laughed, and the laugh cracked the plaster of the day the way laughter always does when it shows up late.

There was a woman in a window three doors down from Felipe’s café who sold lace doilies and gossip. She had a sugar bowl for secrets. She had eyes like mirrors that had seen and forgiven. She had watched the tall woman go by again in a shirt that had decided to stay on and noted that the tall woman had watched the window of the shop where the braider worked and had changed her pace by half a step, the way a cat changes its pace when it senses the dog across the street has learned to open gates. She told Felipe this because she liked him and because she liked to tell Detective Chamberlain a thing the detective did not already know. Felipe liked that she liked him because he was still the kind of person who collected other people’s preferences as if they were recipes he might make someday. He told Chamberlain and she made her mouth soften in that fractional way people never get to see on television cops, and she said, gracias, with a vowel that made him proud.

They set a watch they pretended wasn’t a watch near the braider’s shop. Reyes borrowed a stool and the braider laughed and told him that stool might eat his ass if he didn’t watch it, and he said if he got eaten he would tell his mother it happened at a righteous place. The braider worked and hummed and yelled at a boy in a white T-shirt to stop pretending a moped was a personality, and she told a long story about a comadre’s husband who had returned from Miami with a haircut he’d bought at the airport and a new love for chia seeds. Chamberlain drifted in and out of doorways like someone who had learned that sometimes being absolutely present makes you visible for the wrong reasons. The chalk woman finished her hand and drew another to hold it, the second not a mirror of the first but a stranger’s hand, and the space between them became the space where messengers pass offerings. The day leaned hard into evening.

Jolea did what she always did when the world began to thrum at pitch. She made a list of the things that would make the noise less rude. She washed two dishes that were not dirty. She folded a shirt she would not wear tomorrow. She wrote a word on three empty scraps of paper and put each in a different pocket. She turned a jar lid until her wrist felt the truth of its own design. She looked in a mirror and practiced her face, not because she needed to trick anyone, but because she wanted to remember which of her faces belonged to now. Then she went to the back of the building where the goods elevator groaned like an old man making a young man’s mistake, and she pushed the button and let the machine call her a sinner. She rode it down to the level where the building smelled like rust and algae. She stepped into the hallway and it felt like the beginning of a bad joke. Two bars, a church and a gallery share a toilet and a ceiling. She laughed softly and the laugh tasted of lemon oil and of a belt you have to loosen if you’re going to survive the night.

The volunteer at the church with the mustache left a note for the detective because he was a person who did not know how not to participate in the improvement of a story. He said that the woman who had left the glove in vinegar had come back to stand on the steps and look at the jar as if it had said something rude to her and she was trying to decide whether to laugh or to teach it manners. He said he’d been ashamed of himself for being curious because curiosity has teeth and he was tired of bleeding. He said he had asked God for a recipe and had been given a proverb, which had annoyed him. Chamberlain read it and put it in her pocket because proverbs are like seeds and they sprout at inconvenient times and often enter rooms with bare feet.

The blue-chair gallery had hired an overnight guard because after the first crate it had become clear that spending on security felt like atonement. The guard had been a boxer when he was a boy and his hands now trembled so slightly, not with fear but with the kindness of a body that has held too much electricity too long. He watched the canvas with the woman kneeling and muttered to her as if she were his aunt, and it kept him from needing to leave every five minutes to check locks that had already locked. The crate’s lid lay against a wall like a sled after children have grown up. The jar with the pearl in it sat in its plastic cradle in an evidence room and did not know that it had become famous. The chalk birds slept under shoes and rain, and the chalk hands kept each other company with the flat joy of shadows.

When the storm at last decided to take itself seriously, it was after midnight and the island had begun to think the thunder had forgotten them. The rain came with theater and a punctuality that made old women set down remote controls and sigh with relief. The gutters took their first drink with greed, then settled into the long swallow. Cops stuck in cars texted their enemies because storms sell truce. Lovers promised to move here someday because rainwashed cities trick you about rent. Sometime in the blue hour within the black, the alley behind the braider’s shop offered itself to a woman who moved like a person who stretches before lifting and like a person who knows the tradition of not showing all your height. Reyes, who had lost a battle with coffee around ten, woke with the prickle of a mosquito choosing him and the intuition that his eyes should ask for more light. Chamberlain, who had learned to count past drowsiness while she brushed her teeth at age twelve, was already stepping into the rain without hurry. The woman in the long sleeves had a bag, the bag rode light on her. Her hands were visible for a second when she adjusted the strap, broad backs, faint fur, the backs of crabs.

Reyes stood up so slowly his bones could have been shy. He did not shout because he was not theatrical unless frying food. He said señora as if he were at a bakery counter. She turned her head like a person who doesn’t mind who says her name because she has decided what to do no matter who speaks. Her face was a study in something more complicated than beauty. She had made no effort to cut herself into a palatable shape. Her eyes put their hands up in a gesture that could have been surrender but wasn’t. Chamberlain was at the other mouth of the alley and the rain stitched lines across her vision that made everything look like a film that couldn’t decide on an ending. She had the odd, unhelpful thought that if this were a dance floor, she would be impressed with the way the woman owned the edge of space.

“Luna,” Reyes said, at random and on purpose.

She smiled and it did two things at once, it made the night nicer and made you wish to have been somewhere else where niceness could not trick you. “We always love a good moon,” she said. Her voice had the richness of language that doesn’t go thin under pressure. She did not step forward and she did not step back, which is the way you stand when you intend to write the next sentence yourself. The braider, who had woken the second the storm punched the mosquitoes from the air, was in her doorway with her arms crossed under her breasts like goddesses in old paintings who have judged everybody equally. Felipe, at his window, held a hand to the pane as if that might put a barrier between his decision to be a citizen and his decision to outlive his own kindness.

Chamberlain felt the city lean in, the way an audience leans when a dancer runs toward the edge of the stage and you remember the time a dancer didn’t stop.
